content.rendered:
In addition to the original game, many more were made Minecraft Editions released for different platforms.

Java Edition[]

the Java Edition is the original game. It runs on Java technology, which makes it playable on any device that has Java installed, regardless of the operating system. To do this, you need the associated launcher program to start. It can be changed and expanded by players with their own resource packs, data packs, skins and modifications. There are no paid add-ons. The game is produced by the Swedish company Mojang.

The Java Edition consists of client and server. For single player mode the client contains an integrated server, for multiplayer mode the server is installed and configured separately from the clients. Anyone can run such a Minecraft server. There is also a wide range of free, public servers.

logo device description Price publication Current version article
personal computer Initially, the version could only be played in the browser, since Alpha 1.0.0 Mojang has had a launcher. €23.95 First release in early alpha stage: May 17, 2009
Official full version: November 18, 2011		 1.18.2 link
personal computer In the Chinese version of the Java Edition, the Forge modification is integrated. The game’s adjustments to the Chinese market are all made through modifications. The game can only be launched using NetEase’s dedicated launcher. free, but add-ons are chargeable Beta: August 8, 2017 The game shows
no version number		 link

Bed Rock Edition[]

the Bed Rock Edition was programmed independently of the Java Edition, originally only for mobile devices. Her name was then Pocket edition and was developed by Mojang alone. Over time, various offshoots emerged, which were mainly developed by the American Microsoft subsidiary Microsoft Studios, such as B. the Windows 10 Edition. In September 2017, some offshoots and a former console edition were integrated into the Bedrock Edition and this only Minecraft mentioned without further addition. With the transition of the PlayStation 4 Edition to the Bedrock Edition on December 10, 2019, the Bedrock Edition is the only active development version of Minecraft besides the Java Edition and all console editions have been retired.

The name Bed Rock Edition is not at stake, but is used by the manufacturer and the community to distinguish this version from the others. The Bedrock Edition and its offshoots are written in the C++ programming language. In contrast to the Java Edition, there were no options for changing the game for a long time. Some of these have since been added, but as paid add-ons that can be purchased via the integrated marketplace, as well as limited game modifications as so-called add-ons.

 This edition was originally Pocket edition and appeared first for Android, then for other touchscreen mobile devices. Later this edition expanded to other platforms:

  • Windows 10 devices, including PCs (in addition to the Java Edition)
  • Amazon Fire TV devices that connect to televisions
  • Xbox One
  • Nintendo switch
  • PlayStation 4

main edition[]

The first was the Java Edition, development of which began in 2009 as “Minecraft”. For a long time, she has dictated the content that has been post-programmed since 2011 for the Bedrock Edition and since 2012 for the Console Edition.

When several editions were merged into “Minecraft” (Bedrock Edition) in September 2017 as part of the Better Together Update, while the previous “Minecraft” was now called “Java Edition”, it gave the impression that the Bedrock Edition was now the main Edition that specifies the content. But that wasn’t the case. Rather, the Java Edition team in Stockholm/Sweden and the Bedrock Edition team in Redmond/USA have been working together on new updates ever since. The first update co-developed in this way was the Aquatic update, which began development after the Better Together update.

There is no longer a main edition, as confirmed by Helen Angel: “We don’t have a core or main edition. Minecraft is just Minecraft.”[1].

Renamed editions[]

The Bedrock Codebase editions were initially released with different, platform-specific logos. As part of the Better Together update, which enables playing together on mobile devices, Windows 10 PCs and consoles, the Pocket edition in Minecraft renamed without further addition. The other editions of the Bedrock Codebase affected by this update also lost their distinct logo, but will continue to be developed for their platform. At the same time, the Java Editionwhich was previously the sole name Minecraft carried, in Minecraft: Java Edition renamed.

Discontinued Editions[]
